Bijections

Bijections from flowjax.bijections.

class Bijection(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: ABC, Module

Basic bijection class. All bijections should support conditioning variables (even if ignored).

cond_dim: int
abstract transform(x: Any, condition: Optional[Any] = None) → Any[source]

class Transformer(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: ABC, Module

Bijection which facilitates parameterisation with a neural network output (e.g. as in coupling flows, or masked autoressive flows). Should not contain (directly) trainable parameters.

abstract transform(x: Any, *args: Any) → Any[source]

Apply transformation.

abstract transform_and_log_abs_det_jacobian(x: Any, *args: Any) → tuple[source]

Apply transformation and compute log absolute value of the Jacobian determinant.

abstract inverse(y: Any, *args: Any) → Any[source]

Invert the transformation.

inverse_and_log_abs_det_jacobian(x: Any, *args: Any) → tuple[source]

Invert the transformation and compute the log absolute value of the Jacobian determinant.

abstract num_params(dim: int) → int[source]

Total number of parameters required for bijection.

abstract get_ranks(dim: int) → Any[source]

The ranks of the parameters, i.e. which dimension of the input the parameters correspond to.

abstract get_args(params: Any) → List[Any][source]

Transform unconstrained vector of params (e.g. nn output) into args for transformation.

class TriangularAffine(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

__init__(loc: Any, arr: Any, lower: bool = True, min_diag: float = 1e-06, weight_normalisation: bool = False)[source]

Transformation of the form Ax + b, where A is a lower or upper triangular matrix. To ensure invertiblility, diagonal entries should be positive (and greater than min_diag).

Parameters

  • loc (Array) – Translation.

  • arr (Array) – Matrix.

  • lower (bool, optional) – Whether the mask should select the lower or upper triangular matrix (other elements ignored). Defaults to True.

  • min_diag (float, optional) – Minimum value on the diagonal, to ensure invertibility. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • weight_log_scale (Optional[Array], optional) – If provided, carry out weight normalisation, initialising log scales to the zero vector.

dim: int
cond_dim: int
diag_idxs: Any
tri_mask: Any
min_diag: float
lower: bool
loc: Any
weight_log_scale: Optional[Any]
property arr

Get triangular array, (applies masking and min_diag constraint).

class BlockAutoregressiveNetwork(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

__init__(key: PRNGKeyArray, dim: int, cond_dim: int, depth: int, block_dim: int, activation: Optional[Callable] = None)[source]

Block Autoregressive Network (see https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.04676).

Parameters

  • key (KeyArray) – Jax PRNGKey

  • dim (int) – Dimension of the distribution.

  • cond_dim (int) – Dimension of extra conditioning variables.

  • depth (int) – Number of hidden layers in the network.

  • block_dim (int) – Block dimension (hidden layer size is roughly dim*block_dim).

  • activation (Callable, optional) – Activation function. Defaults to _BlockTanh.

dim: int
depth: int
layers: list
cond_dim: int
block_dim: int

class Coupling(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

Coupling layer implementation (https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.08803).

Parameters

  • key (KeyArray) – Jax PRNGKey

  • transformer (Transformer) – Transformer to be parameterised by the conditioner neural netork.

  • d (int) – Number of untransformed conditioning variables.

  • D (int) – Total dimension.

  • cond_dim (int) – Dimension of additional conditioning variables.

  • nn_width (int) – Neural network hidden layer width.

  • nn_depth (int) – Neural network hidden layer size.

  • nn_activation (Callable, optional) – Neural network activation function. Defaults to jnn.relu.

class MaskedAutoregressive(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

__init__(key: ~jax._src.prng.PRNGKeyArray, transformer: ~flowjax.bijections.abc.Transformer, dim: int, cond_dim: int, nn_width: int, nn_depth: int, nn_activation: ~typing.Callable = <jax._src.custom_derivatives.custom_jvp object>) → None[source]

Masked autoregressive bijection implementation (https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07057v4). The transformer is parameterised by a neural network, with weights masked to ensure an autoregressive structure.

Parameters

  • key (KeyArray) – Jax PRNGKey

  • transformer (Transformer) – Transformer to be parameterised by the autoregressive network.

  • dim (int) – Dimension.

  • cond_dim (int) – Dimension of any conditioning variables.

  • nn_width (int) – Neural network width.

  • nn_depth (int) – Neural network depth.

  • nn_activation (Callable, optional) – Neural network activation. Defaults to jnn.relu.

cond_dim: int
transformer: Transformer
autoregressive_mlp: AutoregressiveMLP

class TanhLinearTails(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

Tanh bijection, with linear “tails” beyond +/- max_val. Note due to the linear tails this does not guarantee the forward transformation will be constrained to [-1, 1]. This transform can be useful to “encourage” values to be within an interval (e.g. to subsequently apply some transformation defined on that interval), whilst avoiding issues with numerical instability.

cond_dim: int = 0
__init__(max_val: float)[source]

Create a tanh bijection with linear “tails” beyond +/- max_val.

Parameters

max_val (int) – Value above or below which the function becomes linear.

max_val: float
property linear_grad
property intercept

class ScannableChain(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

__init__(bijection: Bijection)[source]

Repeatedly apply the same bijection with different parameter values. Internally, uses jax.lax.scan to reduce compilation time.

The array leaves in bijection should have an additional leading axis to scan over. Often it is convenient to construct these using equinox.filter_vmap. For example

` params = jnp.ones((3, 2)) affine = ScannableChain(equinox.filter_vmap(Affine)(params)) ` This would be equivilent to Chain([Affine(p) for p in params]).

Parameters

bijections (Bijection) – A bijection, in which the arrays have an additional leading axis to scan over.

params: Any
static: Any
cond_dim: int
transform(x, condition=None)[source]

transform_and_log_abs_det_jacobian(x, condition=None)[source]

class Invert(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

__init__(bijection: Bijection)[source]

Invert a bijection, such that the transform methods become the inverse methods and vice versa. Note that in general, we define bijections such that the forward methods are preffered, i.e. faster/actually implemented. For training flows, we generally want the inverse method (used in density evaluation), to be faster. Hence it is often useful to use this class to achieve this aim.

Parameters

bijection (Bijection) – Bijection to “invert”.

bijection: Bijection
cond_dim: int

class EmbedCondition(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Bijection

__init__(bijection: Bijection, embedding_net: Module, cond_dim: int) → None[source]

Use an embedding network to reduce the dimensionality of the conditioning variable. The returned bijection has cond_dim equal to the raw condition size.

Parameters

  • bijection (Bijection) – Bijection with bijection.cond_dim equal to the embedded size.

  • embedding_net (eqx.Module) – A callable equinox module that embeds a conditioning variable to size bijection.cond_dim.

  • cond_dim (int) – The dimension of the raw conditioning variable.

bijection: Bijection
embedding_net: Module
cond_dim: int
